Ingmar Bergman, in the midst of his prime, and following two other heavily psychological films, Persona and Hour of the Wolf, is far more interested in seeing what the effect of war has on usually civilized beings, that it brings out the worst in them, and also in a cathartic way is a reminder of what is truly crucial in living. < br / > < br / > And the deconstruction of the relationship between Jan and Eva is corresponded successfully with the backdrop of a chaotic kind of war - ground where the lines are never too surely drawn. When there is war action it's shot in unconventional, quick ways ( via great amigo Sven Nykvist ).
A gruelling watch, but one of Bergman's finest films. The flaws become all that is left as his humanity is gradually eroded by one horror after another.

But what about war? Jan is at first an idealist, unable to react properly to the world and a subject to his wife's will. In Skammen that idea is extended to a complex analysis of the dehumanizing nature of war. This creates a huge tension and makes every event meaningful.

Nor is this a romanticisation of war or patriotism, unlike most war movies. Through much of the film they are spectators, much as we are. < br / > < br / > Highly recommended. 10 / 10 Bergman's Skammen is one of the most realistic depictions of war ever set to film.
